entry.title: New cooling breakthrough nearly doubles efficiency
entry.summary: CHESS thin-film materials nearly double refrigeration efficiency compared to traditional methods. Scalable and versatile, they promise applications from household cooling to space exploration.

entry.title: Light-powered chip makes AI 100 times more efficient
entry.summary: Artificial intelligence is consuming enormous amounts of energy, but researchers at the University of Florida have built a chip that could change everything by using light instead of electricity for a core AI function. By etching microscopic lenses directly onto silicon, they’ve enabled laser-powered computations that cut power use dramatically while maintaining near-perfect accuracy.

entry.title: A tiny chip may have solved one of clean energy’s biggest problems
entry.summary: In just one afternoon, scientists used a nanoparticle “megalibrary” to find a catalyst that matches or exceeds iridium’s performance in hydrogen fuel production, at a fraction of the cost.

entry.title: Why recycling ‘dead’ batteries could save billions and slash pollution
entry.summary: Lithium battery recycling offers a powerful solution to rising demand, with discarded batteries still holding most of their valuable materials. Compared to mining, recycling slashes emissions and resource use while unlocking major economic potential. Yet infrastructure, policy, and technology hurdles must still be overcome.

entry.title: AI just found 5 powerful materials that could replace lithium batteries
entry.summary: AI is helping scientists crack the code on next-gen batteries that could replace lithium-ion tech. By discovering novel porous materials, researchers may have paved the way for more powerful and sustainable energy storage using abundant elements like magnesium.

entry.title: Scientists discover salt that makes batteries last 10x longer
entry.summary: A team at KAUST has revealed that the short lifespan of aqueous batteries is primarily due to "free water" molecules triggering harmful chemical reactions at the anode. By adding affordable sulfate salts like zinc sulfate, they significantly reduced this issue—boosting battery life over tenfold. The sulfate acts as a “water glue,” stabilizing the water structure and halting the energy-wasting reactions. Not only is this solution simple and cost-effective, but early results suggest it may be a universal fix for various types of metal-anode aqueous batteries.

entry.title: You hear the beep, but can’t find the car: The hidden flaw in electric vehicle safety
entry.summary: As electric vehicles grow more popular, their warning sounds may not be doing enough to protect pedestrians. A Swedish study shows that these signals are hard to locate, especially when multiple vehicles are involved, leaving people unable to tell where danger is coming from or how many cars are nearby.

entry.title: Discovery could boost solid-state battery performance
entry.summary: Researchers have discovered that the mixing of small particles between two solid electrolytes can generate an effect called a 'space charge layer,' an accumulation of electric charge at the interface between the two materials. The finding could aid the development of batteries with solid electrolytes, called solid-state batteries, for applications including mobile devices and electric vehicles.

entry.title: Listening to electrons talk
entry.summary: Researchers present new experimental and theoretical results for the bound electron g-factor in lithium-like tin which has a much higher nuclear charge than any previous measurement. The experimental accuracy reached a level of 0.5 parts per billion. Using an enhanced interelectronic QED method, the theoretical prediction for the g-factor reached a precision of 6 parts per billion.

entry.title: EV battery recycling key to future lithium supplies
entry.summary: Lightweight, powerful lithium-ion batteries are crucial for the transition to electric vehicles, and global demand for lithium is set to grow rapidly over the next 25 years. A new analysis looks at how new mining operations and battery recycling could meet that demand. Recycling could play a big role in easing supply constraints, the researchers found.

entry.title: Adsorptive membrane for PFAS removal - Nature Water
entry.summary: Efficient, low-cost removal of trace per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) from water is challenging to achieve. Low-pressure adsorptive membranes that are easy to regenerate have great potential for removing trace contaminants such as PFASs from aqueous systems.

entry.title: Electrostatic-based transfer keeps 2D materials ultra-clean
entry.summary: A technique that spontaneously detaches a 2D material from the substrate on which it was grown creates high-quality nanoscale electronic devices.

entry.title: Breaking symmetry in time to protect light - Nature Nanotechnology
entry.summary: Topologically protected states in a photonic crystal can prevent backscattering of light, but creating these states requires the photonic crystal to be engineered to break time-reversal symmetry. Major strides have been taken towards this goal using a photonic crystal driven by a circularly polarized laser.

entry.title: Soft robotics for personalized and sustainable wearables - Nature Reviews Bioengineering
entry.summary: Soft robotic systems can be integrated into wearable technologies, offering adaptable and safe solutions for assistance, rehabilitation and haptic feedback. This Review explores key soft actuator technologies, integration strategies and the role of sustainability in enabling personalized, energy-efficient and durable wearable soft robotic devices.
